Message.Title: While nvidia dawdles, TI has captured another new market -- Wireless Charging
Message.Msg: Wireless charging, boys. THE hottest new invention for mobile devices. And Texas Instruments has captured this new market with their wireless charging IC's. Texas Instruments currently leads communications IC suppliers in the development of wireless charging chips, serving as the sole supplier of related chips to Nokia and HTC. Meanwhile, Jen dawdles with this and that... and stretches the "Roadmap" by another year. Read all about it, boys. That hot new area of wireless charging -- which nvidia is clueless about. Maybe nvidia will get into it someday, if ARM starts selling the licenses, right boys? Ha ha ha ha ha!. More smartphones to feature wireless charging Cage Chao, Taipei; Steve Shen, DIGITIMES [Friday 16 November 2012] Smartphone vendors... are expected to roll out new models with wireless charging functionality as a basic feature in 2013, according to industry sources. Japan-based vendors and Nokia have led the trend by releasing a number of smartphones with wireless charging, and Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics have also started adding the same functionality to their new models, the sources noted. HTC, which has seen its sales decline recently, also plans to roll out new phones with wireless charging in the fourth quarter of 2012, the sources added. Besides, US-based telecom carrier Verizon Wireless has begun to offer customized high-end smartphone models with wireless charging, highlighting the rapid commercialization of wireless charging application, the sources commented. Texas Instruments (TI) currently leads communications IC suppliers in the development of wireless charging chips, serving as the SOLE SUPPLIER of related chips to Nokia and HTC at present. Integrated Device Technology (IDT) is also moving into the segment, and has signed cooperation agreements with Intel and Qualcomm, respectively, aiming to deepen its development in wireless charging chips and applications, the sources indicated. There is a possibility for Apple to include wireless charging application into its next-generation iPhone due to the increasing popularity of the technology, the sources commented.

Message.Title: TI Cuts 1,700 Jobs, Exits Mobile Chip Market
Message.Msg: "Texas Instruments said it will lay off about 1,700 workers, or about 5% of its total workforce, as part of a restructuring that will see it exit the market for mobile chips that power smartphones and tablets, including Amazon's Kindle Fire."

Topic.Title: Can't believe how this stock is being beat up...

Message.Msg: Headed for single digits, no matter what. Good earnings, positive guidance, stock buyback, initiate a dividend, it all doesn't matter. MM's, hedge funds want this stock gone, that's for sure. Analyst's don't believe this is a viable company going forward, another AMD can't compete with the BIG boys on the block. Heck even TI folded, cashed in their share of the mobile market and you think NVDA can compete?

Topic.Title: Can't believe how this stock is being beat up...

Message.Msg: let me spell it out exactly how bad it is going to get sales $ wise: Q3 $240M sales Q4, with all of Nov for X'mas ships, forecast is for only $160M god know when wayne will come to market in 2013, they have no chips yet, just like Grey. If, huge if, everything works right, chip introduction in late Q2, sales won't come in before Q2 14. in cc, they are still ramping r&d for Tegra, all while sales continue to decline for the next 5+Qs. Breakeven is now well over $300M/Q for tegra now. care to add up how much nvda shareholders will lose in tegra over the next 5Qs? Wayne's r&d began perhaps mid-'2010, it is just stringing ARM's core. it would have taken them 3 years to get the chip to market!!! That's way after all the competition having A15s out. And you want them to design their own core and outperform ARM's too?? nvda does not have the cpu design expertise to compete in this area and it shows. Everybody else is doing a much better job/a whole year's lead on nvda.

"When is Jen going to finally release the nvidia 10-Q?" Why, that's fine question, director.best. Jen launched the sensationalized headlines a week ago Thursday. But there is still no fact-filled 10-Q available for the investor community. nvidia needs to get more like Apple, you know. Apple releases their 10-Q report much faster than nvidia. Much Much Faster. Like, THE DAY AFTER THE EARNINGS ANNOUNCEMENT. It's true. And remember, Apple is a much much larger enterprise than nvidia. Much Much Larger. So they have oh so much more accounting to do. For example, Apple has 70 Times the EBITDA that little nvidia has. Yet they get their financial results to their lucky investors, well, Faster. Like, THE DAY AFTER THE EARNINGS ANNOUNCEMENT. Not a week ago last Thursday -- and we're all still waiting on it. Maybe another management issue here, right boys?

So Best? You successfully managed to get Jen to pay us shareholders a dividend. The First Ever Nvidia Dividend in the 19 year history of this place. "The Best little dividend, ever." For which us shareholders are deeply grateful to you. Deeply grateful. So Best? Do you think you can get the dawdling Accounting Department to get us our 10-Q Report a little faster too? Like Apple does. Thanks ever so much, Best!

"You successfully managed to get Jen to pay us shareholders a dividend. The First Ever Nvidia Dividend in the 19 year history of this place. "The Best little dividend, ever." For which us shareholders are deeply grateful to you. Deeply grateful. So Best? Do you think you can get the dawdling Accounting Department to get us our 10-Q Report a little faster too? Like Apple does." Well, thanks for the kind words, boys. And sure, Best can put it on his growing list of Shareholder Demands. Let's see here... #37. Get the 10-Q out the Day After the earnings snnouncement. Got it.

Jeepers Best, You seem to be a fine, astute Manager of Managers. A Boss with the Right Stuff. Genuine Presidental Timber, as it were. I bet your own rapidly growing collection of global enterprises runs like a Swiss watch. Say! Maybe you should be in charge of Jen's dawdling "Roadmap"? And get those new chips out -- in the same year they are supposed to be out. Rollin' Rollin' Rollin' Keep movin', movin', movin', Though they're disapprovin', Keep them doggies movin' Rawhide! Move 'em on, head 'em up, Head 'em up, move 'em out, Move 'em on, head 'em out Rawhide!

Speaking of Jen's stock options as we were, Best would make a change there too. His "Roadmap for New Chips". Jen either meets the Roadmap deadlines -- or it's No stock options for Jen. Seems entirely fair, right? It sure does. If those stock options aren't for delivering the goods, what the heck ARE they for?

Companies might also help investors by paying a so-called "special dividend," or a one-time payout, before year-end to help them avoid potentially higher taxes later. "The number of special dividends is likely to spike in the next (six weeks)," says Dan Clifton, a policy analyst at Strategas. A bunch of companies have already announced special dividends, including IDT, FedFirst Financial, NIC, Commerce Bancshares, Southside Bancshares, Sinclair and Watsco, according to Jeff Hoopes, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Michigan. Special dividend by NVDA would have been better for shareholdlers(bagholders), than initiating a regular dividend. NVDA screws up one mo time....whaafkupcompanydisis!!!

Message.Title: Nvidia's Prospects?
Message.Msg: Nvidia's mobile processors have done well in Non-Apple tablets but not so well in smartphones. The new Tegra 4 processor needs to be a clear winner. Anyone have any information on this upcoming release? With AMD nearing irrelevance Nvidia will be the last company making discrete GPUs. This will be a positive for Nvidia's revenue and profits but IMHO will not do much for the stock price
Hope you are the real j777kxx...good to have you back if you are... Tegra 4 will either be launched at CES or MWC in Q1 2013

Immediately. And then maybe Jen can put the cash towards something useful. Like designing chips for wireless charging. Like Texas Instruments did.

Yes I am j777kxx. Two things happened to peak my interest again in Nvidia. 1) The dividend announcement which is a positive. 2) TI dropping out of the mobile processor market. Seems positive for Nvidia at first. But TI has a long history of dropping out of markets when they see a market that they cannot dominate. They have been right each time. I really wonder what Nvidia sees that TI doesn't? Qualcomm and Samsung sure look every bit as strong as Intel was at the dawn of PC. Looking for something that would make me think Nvidia has was it takes to win in mobile other than being the last competitor to go up against those two. Not worried about Apple, they will do their thing. Any ideas?
Oh, I almost forgot. #39. CEO Jen meets the "Roadmap for New Chips", or it's No stock options for Jen.

But with Kepler integrated GPUs... no doubt NVidia will have lots of eye candy when they do launch...but with 3d graphics requirements for small screens... other GPU architectures, such as ARM & IMG, will produce very fast results for low polygon counts... Nvidia's future is Project Denver...time will tell...

Topic.Title: This post is in reply to Getanid's message....

Message.Msg: I am completely confused. I go away for 3 months and you tell me Nvidia's management has grown up! No more beat the drums into CES in January and Barcelonia in February. This was the most dependable short term swing trade in the semiconductor universe. Is it gone? Frankly this shocking. Not to mention a dividend along with the complete collapse of AMD in graphics share, Gross margin above 53% with the very real possibility of AMD going belly up leaving Nvidia as the one and only supplier of GPUs. Yet the stock is is almost single digits.

"No doubt Nvidia will have lots of eye candy when they do launch Tegra 4 ... with 3d graphics requirements for small screens." { sigh } Does Jen do Any surveys at all of what consumers actually want? Hummm? Before pizzing-away Hundreds of Millions of shareholder's cash on R&D. And years of development time. Building new graphics chips -- with 3d graphics that Nobody wants. NOBODY. Did Jen learn NOTHING from his prior two failures of 3d graphics? { sigh } Tegra #4 -- Another delayed tegra with "3d graphics for a tiny screen". Look. Folks didn't like 3d graphics on a big screen. They didn't like 3d graphics on a medium screen. And guess what? They're not going to like 3d graphics on a tiny screen either. Jen REALLY needs to be doing customer surveys on this stuff. It's easy. You show the person 3d graphics, and ask them "Do you like it?" And then pay careful attention to their response. "I do not like that 3d stuff I would not like it here or there. I would not like it anywhere. I would not like it in my house. I would not like it with a mouse. I would not use it in the dark. I would not take it to the park. I would not like it on a large screen. I would not like it on a medium screen. I would not like it on a teeny tiny screen. I do not like that 3d stuff I would not use it Anywhere. And that, boys and girl, might have saved nvidia Hundreds of Millions of shareholder's cash wasted on the tegra #4 -- "with 3d graphics for small screens". 3d graphics -- it's a scratch, boys. Here or there.

Topic.Title: This post is in reply to Getanid's message....

Message.Msg: "The very real possibility of AMD going belly up leaving Nvidia as the one and only supplier of add-on GPU chips. Frankly this shocking." Yes, folks were shocked. When the math co-processors bit the dust too. Remember the circa-1980's Motorola 68881/68882 math co-processors? Gone. Killed-off by the vastly improved floating point arithmetic functions of Intel CPU processors. And so it will be with Intel CPU's + Integrated Graphics. The need for nvidia's add-on graphics processors will be made obsolete as well. The good news is -- the last add-on GPU maker left in existence -- likely nvidia -- gets to claim 100% market share. Right up to the point that they close their doors, Forever.

Topic.Title: Some numbers from SC12 - either announced or known/confirmed

Message.Msg: Intel Xeon Phi 5110P cluster tops Green 500 list Nvidia needs to take note By Lawrence Latif Thu Nov 15 2012, 14:52 CHIPMAKER Intel has seen the Xeon Phi accelerated Beacon cluster claim top spot in the Green 500 list. As AMD and Nvidia celebrated their position at the summit of the Top 500 list that ranks publicly known high performance computing clusters based on Linpack performance, Intel scored what many would claim is an equally important Victory. Appro's Xeon powered Beacon cluster that features Xeon Phi 5110P accelerator cards topped the Green 500 list. Intel will be particularly happy with its top billing in the Green 500 list, which divides the Linpack performance number by the cluster's power usage to produce a MFLOPS/W value. Appro's Beacon cluster scored 2,500 MFLOPS/W, almost 150 MFLOPS/W higher than the second place cluster and over 250 MFLOPS/W higher than the AMD and Nvidia powered Titan cluster that sits on top of the Top 500 list. Appro, which was bought by Cray last week, is only one of four vendors including Cray to make it into the Green 500's top 10. Most of those systems are IBM Bluegene clusters that use 16-core Power processors, though Cray and Appro take three of the top five spots, with Adtech coming in at number two on the list. Nvidia could rightfully claim that the interconnect, the wires that connect the nodes in the cluster, is different. Appro's Beacon cluster uses the mature Infiniband interconnect while the two Cray clusters that feature Nvidia's Tesla K20 and Tesla K20X accelerator cards use Cray's leading edge Gemini interconnect that could see future improvements to reduce power utilisation. Intel's Xeon Phi accelerator doesn't boast the same double-precision floating point peak TeraFLOPS rating as Nvidia's Tesla K20X, however given that the Xeon Phi *** already has higher power efficiency than the Nvidia accelerator cards *** its future looks promising. µ Numero Uno, boys. The Intel Xeon Phi 5110P accelerator cards. For the #1 Best, most power-efficient HPC computing. Google it boys : Intel Xeon Phi 5110P cluster tops Green 500 list
